title: Is the 'Law of Cause and Effect' true? - Quora

response.answer_text: With all due respect to Brian Tracy, such an idea is utterly ridiculous outside of very general rules for engagement. Let's consider reality as three layers: 1) socio-cultural structures, 2) that which is personally controllable, 3) that which isn't personally controllable. (I'd be more pedantic, but am keeping this simple for brevity.) The structures of one's socio-cultural context include both the mores for interpersonal engagement and the physical constructs of industry. These will determine to a large extent what is possible for "success," at least within that context. It's little wonder that a great many people of one culture find financial and social success when taking what they have into another culture, because staying in their original place wasn't going to result in anything personally profound. Further, systems are in place, which if not understood and capable of being manipulated, will curtail potential ideas and behavior. What is possible for someone at a high level of social power will result in destruction for someone at a lower level. There are any number of things that are personally uncontrollable, from one's biology to familial status to generational variables like poverty. Undoubtedly millions of brilliant people exist that will never see the light of day due to things outside their control.  That being said, the things that are personally controllable can shift and change depending on what choices are made.  What "cause and effect" means is not one cause for one effect, but the inevitability of consequence for all behavior. What those consequences are will be determined by time, location, cultural context, personal skill, etc.
